metadata.name: Treaty Governance Signals
metadata.description: Signals for monitoring treaty health after signature, including collaborative monitoring cues and erosion warnings.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Signals that reveal how multi-tribe treaties are monitored, enforced, adapted, and defended against erosion.

positive_examples: Treaty dashboards aggregate telemetry from all signatories.
Joint secretariat publishes compliance summaries monthly.
Dispute cases are tracked with resolution timelines.
Sanction votes are logged with rationale.
Update proposals cite measured treaty performance.
Observer seats rotate among tribes.
Treaty archives remain searchable for future cohorts.
Communication channels stay open beyond crises.
Cross-tribe drills rehearse response protocols.
Oversight boards review CAT readiness annually.
Mutual aid commitments remain funded.
Breaches trigger pre-agreed escalation ladders.
Adaptation clauses are invoked transparently.
Treaty learnings feed into new negotiations.
Exit procedures are rehearsed without stigma.
negative_examples: Telemetry exists only per tribe with no aggregation.
Secretariat communications go silent for months.
Disputes linger without tracking.
Sanction decisions happen via private phone calls.
Update proposals rely on anecdotes.
Observer seats are captured by a few tribes.
Archives are scattered and inaccessible.
Channels open only when crises occur.
Drills are cancelled to avoid embarrassment.
CAT readiness never gets reviewed jointly.
Mutual aid funds are raided for unrelated needs.
Breaches are ignored until public outcry.
Adaptation clauses are treated as optional.
Lessons learned are not recorded.
Exit procedures are taboo to discuss.

candidates.definition: Coordinated monitoring where every signatory contributes telemetry, probes, and observers to a shared view.

positive_examples: Telemetry feeds from all signatories arrive on the same cadence.
Monitoring dashboards attribute data to each tribe clearly.
Observers flag anomalies and see responses logged.
Probe health is reviewed holistically, not per tribe only.
Fallback coverage is assigned when a tribe has downtime.
Monitoring meetings rotate facilitators.
Mutual verification scripts are shared and versioned.
Frontline operators can page the collective command center.
Shared glossary defines gauges and thresholds.
Monitoring budgets are co-funded proportionally.
Telemetry gaps trigger automated reminders.
CAT overlays show how each tribe contributes sensors.
Monitoring data includes context for local incidents.
Secure enclaves let tribes inspect raw logs when authorized.
Collective metrics remain accessible to treaty-aligned auditors.
negative_examples: Some tribes deliver telemetry weekly, others yearly.
Dashboards aggregate numbers without attribution.
Observer alerts vanish without acknowledgment.
Probe health is tracked only locally.
Downtime leaves blind spots with no backup.
Monitoring chair never changes.
Verification scripts are proprietary.
Operators must escalate through political channels.
Glossary disagreements go unresolved.
Monitoring budgets fall entirely on smaller tribes.
Telemetry gaps accumulate with no follow-up.
CAT overlays show large blind regions.
Context for incidents is missing, so misinterpretations spread.
Raw logs cannot be inspected even under treaty.
Auditors see only local snapshots, not collective metrics.
training_hints.disambiguation: Coordinated monitoring where every signatory contributes telemetry, probes, and observers to a shared view.

candidates.definition: Quality of processes used to investigate breaches, arbitrate outcomes, and enforce remedies without bias.

positive_examples: Cases enter via standard channels with tracking IDs.
Panels include balanced representation and neutral chairs.
Evidence packets are shared with all parties simultaneously.
Hearings are recorded and transcripts distributed.
Interim measures are proportional and reversible.
Decisions cite treaty clauses and telemetry.
Remediation plans include timelines and owners.
Appeal paths are documented and respected.
Retaliation against complainants is forbidden and enforced.
Dispute statistics are published periodically.
Historical precedent is referenced for consistency.
Translation support is provided for all languages.
Independent ombuds attend proceedings.
Learning reviews follow every major case.
Remedy implementation is monitored by the collective.
negative_examples: Complaints require backchannel favors to be heard.
Panels are stacked with one tribe's allies.
Evidence is drip-fed to disadvantage respondents.
Hearings happen without transcripts.
Interim measures punish tribes irreversibly.
Decisions cite vague notions rather than clauses.
Remediation plans are oral promises only.
Appeals are discouraged or ignored.
Whistleblowers face retaliation without protection.
Dispute statistics are secret.
Similar cases get wildly different outcomes.
Translation is ad hoc, leading to misunderstanding.
Ombuds are excluded for 'sensitivity'.
No lessons-learned process exists.
Remedies go unmonitored once headlines fade.
training_hints.disambiguation: Quality of processes used to investigate breaches, arbitrate outcomes, and enforce remedies without bias.

candidates.definition: Structured mechanisms for evolving treaty clauses when conditions change without eroding commitments.

positive_examples: Update triggers tie to telemetry thresholds.
Working groups draft change proposals with full rationale.
Stakeholders beyond signatories are consulted when impacted.
Change windows are scheduled and transparent.
Proposed updates include fallback options.
Simulations test impacts before adoption.
Ratification steps mirror the original legitimacy process.
Historical context is retained in change logs.
Objections are logged with mitigation ideas.
Interoperability with other treaties is considered.
Update packages include verification adjustments.
Secretariat maintains a canonical version history.
Changes are piloted before full enforcement when possible.
Sunset clauses are reviewed alongside updates.
Adaptive capacity metrics are reviewed at governance summits.
negative_examples: Updates happen only after crises, with no triggers.
Proposals lack rationale beyond politics.
Impacted external parties hear about changes after the fact.
Change discussions happen in ad hoc sessions.
No fallback plans exist if changes fail.
Impacts are not tested before enforcement.
Ratification is skipped under 'emergency' banner.
Version history is muddled with conflicting documents.
Objections disappear from minutes.
Other treaties are broken inadvertently.
Verification adjustments are treated as trivial.
Secretariat cannot say which version is current.
Changes go live globally with no pilot.
Sunset clauses are ignored during updates.
Adaptive capacity is never measured.
training_hints.disambiguation: Structured mechanisms for evolving treaty clauses when conditions change without eroding commitments.

candidates.definition: Pattern where breaches are quietly ignored or forgiven without process, undermining the treaty.

positive_examples: Known violations stay off the shared log.
Secretariat asks reporters to drop complaints.
Repeated breaches are reframed as 'misunderstandings'.
Sanction votes are postponed indefinitely.
Problematic tribes are shielded to preserve appearances.
Telemetry anomalies go uninvestigated for months.
Breach reporters are told to use private channels only.
Status reports celebrate positives and omit failures.
Clause owners resign without replacements.
Breaches trigger handshake deals instead of enforcement.
Closed sessions strike breaches from the record.
Apologies replace remediation plans.
Escalation ladders are bypassed entirely.
Treaty dashboard lights stay green despite evidence.
External partners notice noncompliance before signatories do.
negative_examples: All breaches are logged within agreed SLA.
Secretariat encourages transparent reporting.
Violations are described factually and addressed.
Sanction votes occur per schedule.
No tribe is above scrutiny.
Telemetry anomalies trigger investigations quickly.
Reporters can escalate publicly without fear.
Status reports balance successes and failures.
Clause owners are backfilled promptly.
Remediation plans follow breaches automatically.
Closed sessions document decisions fully.
Apologies accompany concrete actions.
Escalation ladders guide responses.
Dashboards change color when metrics warrant.
Signatories detect noncompliance before outsiders do.
training_hints.disambiguation: Pattern where breaches are quietly ignored or forgiven without process, undermining the treaty.

candidates.definition: Warning signs that treaty obligations expand beyond mandate without consent.

positive_examples: Secretariat issues directives not grounded in treaty text.
Working groups claim authority over unrelated domains.
Joint assets are repurposed without vote.
New enforcement powers appear in guidance memos.
Treaty references show up in contracts never approved.
Scope expansions are justified as 'interpretation'.
Observers note language drift in communiqués.
Budget reallocations fund off-mandate projects.
Sanctions are applied for behaviors outside scope.
Scope questions are dismissed as obstruction.
Change control for scope is undefined.
Merged treaties occur without ratification.
Implementation teams cite treaty to enforce local priorities.
Scope diagrams are replaced with ambiguous prose.
Side groups create their own annexes unilaterally.
negative_examples: Secretariat actions cite specific treaty clauses.
Working groups stay within chartered areas.
Asset usage changes go through approvals.
Guidance memos reference voted decisions.
Treaty references in contracts are reviewed.
Interpretations are recorded with sign-off.
Communiqués maintain agreed terminology.
Budgets align with mandate categories.
Sanctions map to clause numbers.
Scope questions are welcomed and answered.
Scope change control is documented.
Treaty mergers require ratification.
Implementers cite treaty accurately.
Scope diagrams remain updated.
Annex creation follows collective process.
training_hints.disambiguation: Warning signs that treaty obligations expand beyond mandate without consent.

candidates.definition: Signals that the coalition underpinning the treaty is splintering, risking collapse.

positive_examples: Sub-groups boycott governance meetings.
Public statements contradict treaty solidarity.
Joint drills lose participants session by session.
Mutual aid contributions drop without explanation.
Side treaties form that undercut shared obligations.
Rumors of exit circulate without formal process.
Delegations stop sharing telemetry citing 'internal issues'.
Coalition chat rooms go quiet except for arguments.
Leadership summits happen without invites to all members.
Observer slots are left vacant.
Working groups duplicate efforts competitively.
Members create parallel governance structures.
Voting blocs harden along factional lines.
Shared branding disappears from communications.
Sanction votes become proxy battles unrelated to breaches.
negative_examples: Attendance remains high across governance forums.
Public statements reinforce treaty unity.
Drills maintain or grow participation.
Mutual aid metrics stay within commitments.
Side treaties reference and respect the main treaty.
Exit rumors are addressed through formal channels.
Telemetry continues to flow from all members.
Coalition chats remain collaborative.
Summits include every member or provide clear reasons.
Observer seats are filled and active.
Working groups coordinate to avoid duplication.
Parallel structures are discouraged.
Voting varies issue by issue, not fixed factions.
Shared branding appears in all communications.
Sanction votes stay focused on actual breaches.
training_hints.disambiguation: Signals that the coalition underpinning the treaty is splintering, risking collapse.
